RT @JECDems In recognition of #BlackHistoryMonth @TheBlackCaucus and @JECDems have released a new analysis of the current economic status of Black Americans, recognizing both the progress that has been made and the challenges that remain.

https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/democrats/issue-briefs?ID=41B9F409-6A97-4B16-932F-5E7E10DC9F3E http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL0t_9hWQAAxRKb.jpg

Black Americans have seen significant economic progress including rising wages, declining poverty & growing graduation rates.

But that doesn‚Äôt mean the work is done‚Äîpolicies & investments for an equitable economy are key to address continuing disparities.
https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/democrats/issue-briefs?ID=41B9F409-6A97-4B16-932F-5E7E10DC9F3E

However, even as college graduation rates have risen among Black students, the gap in the share of Black and white college graduates has remained mostly unchanged. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL0vE2PXEAgQP7l.png

Black Americans have seen improvements in education, with the high school dropout rate declining and the rate of college graduation growing.

Since 1990, the college graduation rate among Black students has more than doubled. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL0u9DzXoAEmER1.jpg

The poverty rate among Black children, in particular, has drastically improved.

While Black children are still more likely to live in poverty than white children, the rate of Black children living in poverty has nearly halved since the 1980s. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL0uwSfWYAACWO4.jpg
I recently helped introduce the School Resource Officer Act to ensure that school districts have the resources and officers needed to keep students safe in the classroom. (2/2)

In 2019, the share of Black Americans living in poverty reached the lowest level on record, an important sign of economic progress.

But Black Americans are still twice as likely to live in poverty as white Americans, highlighting the work still to be done. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL0un9hXEAcaD7E.png

As a father, grandfather, and former first responder, ensuring that our children and grandchildren are safe at school is one of my top priorities. A big part of that is having dedicated school resource officers on campus to respond in emergency situations. (1/2)

Black workers also face disproportionately high unemployment‚Äîdouble the rate seen by white workers.

During most of the past 50 years, Black Americans have experienced unemployment rates that, were they experienced by the entire population, would be seen as recessionary. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL0uVk-XEAcQlSb.png
